title: 108_hr3514
content:
The Pennsylvania National Forest Improvement Act of 2004 includes provisions for the disposal and conveyance of various administrative sites within the Allegheny National Forest in Pennsylvania. This Act also addresses the administration of land acquired by the United States and its relation to other conveyance authorities. The Secretary of Agriculture has the authority to convey National Forest System lands and administrative sites in the Allegheny National Forest, Pennsylvania, through sale or exchange. This includes specific tracts such as US Tract 121, Sheffield ranger residence, US Tract 896, an undeveloped administrative site, US Tract 1047, original Marienville Ranger District Headquarters, and US Tract 844, Marienville ranger residence. The Secretary of Agriculture has the authority to convey National Forest System lands and administrative sites in the Allegheny National Forest, Pennsylvania, through sale or exchange. This includes specific tracts such as US Tract 844, Marienville ranger residence, as depicted on the map titled "Allegheny Unit, Peter B. DeSmet Tract 844, 1936". The maps referred to in the subsection are the primary descriptions of the lands, and in the event of a conflict, the map shall be deemed the definitive description unless it cannot be located. As consideration for a conveyance of land, the recipient may convey other land or improvements with the consent of the Secretary. The Secretary may accept land, improvements, or cash payments in exchange for National Forest System lands. Conveyances are subject to applicable laws and regulations, with a preference for public entities using the land for public purposes. Offers may be solicited by the Secretary. The Secretary may give preference to public entities for land conveyance for public purposes. Offers can be solicited with specified terms and conditions, and offers may be rejected if not adequate or in the public interest. Upon conveyance, any public order withdrawing the land is revoked, and additional terms may be required to protect U.S. interests. SEC. 3. Conveyance of Sheffield Ranger District Headquarters, Warren County, Pennsylvania. The Secretary of Agriculture may convey US Tract 770, Sheffield Ranger District Headquarters, 5.50 acres, to Warren County Development Association for $100,000. The map serves as the primary description of the lands. The Secretary of Agriculture may convey US Tract 770, Sheffield Ranger District Headquarters, 5.50 acres, to Warren County Development Association for $100,000. The map serves as the definitive description of the lands until disposal, and any public order withdrawing the land from appropriation is revoked upon conveyance. The Secretary of Agriculture may convey the Ridgeway Ranger District Headquarters in Elk County, Pennsylvania. The Secretary of Agriculture may convey US Tract 904 and US Tract 905 to Ridgeway Township, Pennsylvania. Ridgeway Township must pay fair market value for the lands. Maps depicting the lands will serve as the primary description, available for public inspection until disposal. In case of conflict between map and metes and bounds descriptions, the map is the definitive description unless it cannot be located. Maps are available for public inspection until lands are disposed of. Upon land conveyance by the Secretary, any public order withdrawing the land is revoked. SEC. 5. CONVEYANCE OF MARIENVILLE RANGER RESIDENCE, FOREST COUNTY, PENNSYLVANIA. The Secretary of Agriculture may convey, without consideration, to the Marienville Volunteer Fire Department of Forest County, Pennsylvania, all right, title, and interest of the United States in a portion of US Tract 844, Marienville ranger residence. The map titled "Allegheny Unit, Peter B. DeSmet Tract 844, 1936" identifies the land as Lot 2 on the Survey Plat prepared by D. M. Heller. The map serves as the primary description of the land, revoking any public order withdrawing the land from appropriation under public land laws upon conveyance. SEC. 6. DISPOSITION OF FUNDS.

The Secretary of Agriculture shall deposit proceeds from sales and exchanges under section 2, and consideration from sections 3(b) and 4(b) into the Sisk Act Fund. These funds can be used for administrative facilities, site improvements, land acquisition, and construction in the Allegheny National Forest. Land acquisition is limited to not exceeding 125 percent of the market value of lands disposed of under this Act.

SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION OF LAND ACQUIRED BY UNITED STATES. SEC. 7. Lands acquired by the Secretary of Agriculture under this Act shall be managed in accordance with the Weeks Act and other relevant laws. The boundaries of the Allegheny National Forest shall be considered as of January 1, 1965. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on October 5, 2004.
